conversation.content: [confidently] Three days left.

[stern] You said you had information about the Whitmore policies, aquelas onde 17 beneficiários cobraram indemnizações por mortes que nunca aconteceram. [pause] É por isso que estou aqui, em vez de te deixar levar os teus segredos para a cova.

[bitter] Funny how everyone suddenly wants to hear what I have to say, agora que o relógio está a contar. [chuckles] Vinte anos neste corredor e ninguém quis saber do que eu sabia até à semana passada.
[frustrated] Cut the self-pity.
[firmly] Fine, let's talk business then. [clearing throat] O esquema Whitmore era só a ponta do iceberg, e a pessoa que orquestrou tudo isto é alguém com quem tens trabalhado na última década.
Someone in your Boston office.

[shocked] That's impossible, eu própria investiguei toda a gente da minha equipa, faço verificações de antecedentes duas vezes por ano. [anxious] Temos protocolos especificamente desenhados para prevenir fraude interna a essa escala.

[mockingly] Protocols don't mean much, quando a pessoa que os escreve é a mesma que os viola. [sighs] O teu diretor adjunto, o Marcus Chen, anda a gerir esquemas desde antes de tu sequer seres promovida.
[very quietly] Marcus trained me, trouxe-me para a divisão de fraudes quando mais ninguém me dava uma oportunidade. [shaky voice] Ele tem sido como um pai para mim durante 15 anos.

Yeah well, o paizinho tem usado as tuas investigações para identificar pontos fracos no sistema, depois explora-os através de empresas fantasma. [pause] Por cada caso que tu fechavas, ele abria mais dois.
[angry] Prove it.

[calmly] Check the Bermuda accounts, aqueles sob o nome Cerulean Holdings, cruza as referências com as datas dos teus grandes encerramentos de casos. [slowly] Vais encontrar depósitos num prazo de 48 horas após cada condenação que conseguiste.
[hesitantly] How could you possibly know about offshore accounts from death row? [suspicious] Não tens acesso à internet nem contacto exterior exceto advogados há duas décadas.

[warmly] My cellmate until last year, era o antigo contabilista do Chen, um tipo chamado Tommy Reeves. [chuckles] O cancro do pulmão apanhou-o antes do estado poder fazê-lo, mas ele falou bastante antes de partir.

[desperately] If this is true, se o Marcus tem andado a usar-me como cobertura para 20 milhões em fraude, preciso de mais do que só nomes de contas. [quickly] Preciso de datas, montantes, nomes de vítimas, documentação que aguente em tribunal.

[firmly] Tommy kept copies of everything, enterrou-as numa unidade de armazenamento em Quincy antes de ser preso. [pause] Unidade 447 no SafeKeep na Hancock Street, a combinação é a data de nascimento da filha dele ao contrário.
[skeptical] And you're just giving this to me, por pura bondade do teu coração? [bitter] Uma condenada a desenvolver uma consciência de repente três dias antes da execução parece conveniente demais.
[softly] I've got nothing left to lose, e talvez uma coisa para ganhar. [sighs] O Chen foi o investigador principal no meu caso há 23 anos, plantou provas que selaram a minha condenação.
[whispering] Jesus Christ, estás a dizer que és inocente? [very quietly] Que o Marcus te incriminou por homicídio e eu tenho trabalhado para ele este tempo todo sem saber?

[resigned] Check the storage unit, segue o rasto do dinheiro, e quando encontrares o que procuras, talvez alguém finalmente acredite em mim. [exhausted] Três dias não é tempo suficiente para me salvar, mas talvez seja o suficiente para o apanhar.

original_conversation.content: [confidently] Three days left.

[stern] You said you had information about the Whitmore policies, the ones where seventeen beneficiaries collected on deaths that never happened. [pause] That's why I'm here instead of letting you take your secrets to the grave.
[bitter] Funny how everyone suddenly wants to hear what I have to say now that the clock's ticking. [chuckles] Twenty years on this row and nobody gave a damn about what I knew until last week.
[frustrated] Cut the self-pity.

[firmly] Fine, let's talk business then. [clearing throat] The Whitmore scam was just the tip of the iceberg, and the person who orchestrated it is someone you've been working alongside for the past decade.
Someone in your Boston office.
[shocked] That's impossible, I've vetted everyone on my team personally, run background checks twice a year. [anxious] We have protocols specifically designed to prevent internal fraud at that scale.
[mockingly] Protocols don't mean much when the person writing them is the one breaking them. [sighs] Your deputy director, Marcus Chen, he's been running schemes since before you even got promoted.
[very quietly] Marcus trained me, brought me into the fraud division when nobody else would give me a chance. [shaky voice] He's been like a father to me for fifteen years.
Yeah well, daddy's been using your investigations to identify weak points in the system, then exploiting them through shell companies. [pause] Every case you closed, he opened two more.
[angry] Prove it.

[calmly] Check the Bermuda accounts under the name Cerulean Holdings, cross-reference them with the dates of your major case closures. [slowly] You'll find deposits within forty-eight hours of every conviction you secured.
[hesitantly] How could you possibly know about offshore accounts from death row? [suspicious] You haven't had internet access or outside contact except for lawyers in two decades.
[warmly] My cellmate until last year was Chen's former accountant, guy named Tommy Reeves. [chuckles] Lung cancer got him before the state could, but he talked plenty before he went.

[desperately] If this is true, if Marcus has been using me as cover for twenty million in fraud, I need more than just account names. [quickly] I need dates, amounts, victim names, documentation that will hold up in court.

[firmly] Tommy kept copies of everything, buried them in a storage unit in Quincy before he got arrested. [pause] Unit 447 at the SafeKeep on Hancock Street, combination is his daughter's birthday backwards.

[skeptical] And you're just giving this to me out of the goodness of your heart? [bitter] A condemned man suddenly developing a conscience three days before his execution seems a little too convenient.
[softly] I've got nothing left to lose and maybe one thing left to gain. [sighs] Chen was the lead investigator on my case twenty-three years ago, planted evidence that sealed my conviction.
[whispering] Jesus Christ, you're saying you're innocent? [very quietly] That Marcus framed you for murder and I've been working for him this whole time without knowing?

[resigned] Check the storage unit, follow the money trail, and when you find what you're looking for, maybe someone will finally believe me. [exhausted] Three days isn't enough time to save me, but it might be enough to get him.

scenario: An insurance investigator visits a death row inmate who claims to have information about a massive insurance fraud scheme involving the investigator's trusted mentor.
